case_name: Raja Narayanlal Bansilal v. Maneck P. Mistry

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 268 of 1959 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 268 of 1959.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated September 3, 1958 of Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 28/1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated September 3, 1958, of the former Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 28/1958.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR J. on August 31, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. August 31. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR J.-

facts.text: Appellant Raja Narayanlal Bansilal is Managing Agent of Harinagar Sugar Mills Limited.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Raja Narayanlal Bansilal of Bombay is the Managing Agent of a Limited Company named the Harinagar Sugar Mills Limited.

facts.text: Registrar wrote to mills on November 15, 1954 under s.137(6) that business carried on in fraud.

anchor.surface_text: By virtue of the power conferred on him by s. 137 of the Indian Companies Act, 1913 (VII of 1913), the Registrar wrote to the mills on November 15, 1954, that it had been represented to him under s. 137(6)

facts.text: Registrar made report Ex. AA to Central Government on April 15, 1955 under s.137(5).

anchor.surface_text: that the business of the company was carried on in fraud, and so he called upon the company to furnish the information which he required as set out in a part of his letter (Ex. A). On April 15, 1955, the Registrar made a report (Ex. AA) to the Central Government under s. 137(5) of the said Act.

facts.text: Report showed affairs carried on in fraud of contributories, unsatisfactory state; appellant Managing Agent and promoter.

anchor.surface_text: This report showed that according to the Registrar the affairs of the company were carried on in fraud of contributories and they disclosed an unsatisfactory state of affairs. The report pointed out that the appellant was the Managing Agent of the company as well as its promoter,

facts.text: Suspected under fictitious Bansilal Uchant Account company advancing money to appellant's firms purchased from company's funds.

anchor.surface_text: and that it was suspected that under a fictitious name of Bansilal Uchant Account the company was advancing money to the several firms owned by the appellant which were ostensibly purchased from the companys funds.

facts.text: Between years ending September 1942 and 1951, Rs. 19,200 paid for Harpur Farm and Rs. 39,300 for Bhavanipur Farm from Uchant Account.

anchor.surface_text: The report further stated that between the years ending in September, 1942 and 1951 about Rs. 19,200 were paid for Harpur Farm and Rs 39,300 for Bhavanipur Farm, and accounts disclosed that the Uchant Account was chiefly operated upon for purchasing such lands out of the funds of the company

facts.text: Central Government passed order Ex. B on November 1, 1955 under s.138(4) appointing Maneck P. Mistry as inspector.

anchor.surface_text: On receiving this report, on November 1, 1955, the Central Government passed an order under s. 138(4) of the said Act (Ex. B) appointing the first respondent Maneck P. Mistry, who is a Chartered Accountant, as an inspector to investigate the affairs of the company from the date of its incorporation.

facts.text: Companies Act 1913 repealed by Companies Act 1956 on April 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Meanwhile on April 1, 1956, the Companies Act of 1913 (VII of 1913) was repealed by the Companies Act of 1956 (1 of 1956).

facts.text: Central Government on July 26, 1956 under s.239(2) new Act approved respondent 1 investigating appellant's affairs and three concerns.

anchor.surface_text: On July 26, 1956, the Central Government purported to exercise its power under s. 239(2) of the new Act and accorded approval to respondent 1 exercising his powers of investigating into, and reporting on, the affairs of the appellant including his personal books of accounts as well as the affairs of the three concerns

facts.text: Three concerns: M/s. Narayanlal Bansilal (Managing Agents), Shangrila Food Products Limited, Harinagar Cane Farm.

anchor.surface_text: specified in the order. These three concerns are M/s. Narayanlal Bansilal, who are the Managing Agents of Harinagar Sugar Mills, the Shangrila Food Products Limited and, Harinagar Cane Farm.

facts.text: Appellant is proprietor of firm Narayanlal Bansilal.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the appellant is the proprietor of the firm of Narayanlal Bansilal.

facts.text: Four notices Ex. E served on appellant on May 9, 1957, May 16, 1957, May 29, 1957, June 29, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: After this order was passed respondent 1 served upon the appellant the four impugned notices (Ex. E collectively) on May 9, 1957, May 16, 1957, May 29, 1957 and June 29, 1957, respectively.

facts.text: Notices required appellant to attend for examination on oath and produce books re company.

anchor.surface_text: These notices are substantially identical in terms and so it would be sufficient for our purpose to set out the purport of one of them. The first notice called upon the appellant to attend the office of respondent 1 on the date and at the time specified for the purpose of being examined on oath in relation to the affairs of the company,

facts.text: Appellant filed petition No. 201 of 1957 in Bombay High Court for writ of certiorari, prohibition etc.

anchor.surface_text: After these notices were served on the appellant he filed a petition (No. 201 of 1957) in the Bombay High Court and prayed that the High Court should issue a writ of certiorari or any other appropriate direction, order or writ under Art. 226 of the Constitution calling upon respondent 1 to produce the records of the case relating to the notices in question and to set aside the said notices,

facts.text: Mr. Justice K.T. Desai rejected petition.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Justice K. T. Desai, who heard the petition, rejected the contentions raised by the petitioner, and held that no case had been made out for the issue of any writ.

facts.text: Bombay High Court Court of Appeal dismissed appeal agreeing with Desai J.

anchor.surface_text: This decision was challenged by the appellant before the Court of Appeal in the Bombay High Court the Court of Appeal agreed with the view taken by Desai, J., and dismissed the appeal.

facts.text: High Court granted certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the appellant applied for and obtained a certificate from the High Court, and it is with the said certificate that he has come to this Court by his present appeal.

facts.text: Petitioner challenged jurisdiction of inspector appointed under old Act to use new Act powers.

anchor.surface_text: He first alleged that since respondent 1 had been appointed under the old Act he had no jurisdiction to exercise powers referable to the relevant provisions of the new Act.

facts.text: Petitioner challenged vires of ss.239 and 240 new Act under Art.20(3) and Art.14.

anchor.surface_text: The other ground on which the writs were claimed challenges the vires of ss. 239 and 240 of the new Act. This challenge assumed an alternative form. It is argued that s. 240 offends against the constitutional guarantee provided by Art. 20(3) of the Constitution and it is also urged that certain portions of ss. 239 and 240 offend against another constitutional guarantee provided by Art. 14 of the Constitution.

facts.text: First respondent Maneck P. Mistry is a Chartered Accountant.

holdings.text: the inspector appointed under s. 138(4) of the old Act must by legal fiction, which is authorised by s. 645, be deemed to have been appointed under s. 235 of the new Act, and if that is so, respondent 1 had authority and power to issue the impugned notices under s. 240 of the new Act

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, in our opinion, the High Court was right in coming to the conclusion that the inspector appointed under s. 138(4) of the old Act must by legal fiction, which is authorised by s. 645, be deemed to have been appointed under s. 235 of the new Act, and if that is so, respondent 1 had authority and power to issue the impugned notices under s. 240 of the new Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.645 provides saving for appointments under old law, deeming them under new Act; s.646 additional not overriding

holdings.text: s. 646 should not be construed as a proviso to s.645 but as an additional saving provision

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept this argument. In appreciating the effect of the provisions of s. 646 it is necessary to bear in mind that it occurs in that part of the new Act which deals with repeals and savings.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Saving sections read independently and additionally; s.646 redundant under s.645 but enacted for caution e.g. banking companies

anchor.surface_text: Now in the light of this test how can it be said that the classification made by ss. 239 and 240 offends Art. 14 of the Constitution ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reasonable classification: company managers distinct with intelligible differentia (abuse in companies) rational to object (protect shareholders)

holdings.text: the classification on which legislation is based is founded on an intelligible differentia which distinguishes persons or things that are grouped together from others left out of the group, and if the differentia has a rational relation to the object sought to be achieved, then the classification does not offend Art. 14
holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies twin test of reasonable classification from precedents like Dalmia case

anchor.surface_text: Our conclusion, therefore, is that s. 240 does not offend against Art. 20(3) of the Constitution. That still leaves the challenge to the vires of the said section under Art. 14 of the Constitution, though we ought to add that Mr. Sastri did not seriously press his case under Art. 14, and we think rightly. The argument under Art. 14 proceeds on familiar lines.

outcome.relief_summary: Challenges to jurisdiction of inspector and vires of ss. 239 and 240 under Arts. 20(3) and 14 rejected; impugned notices upheld

edges.explanation: Argument a1 rebuts the deeming effect of c11 (s.645) by arguing no jurisdiction under new Act powers, invoking s.646.
Petitioner's argument a1 directly addresses the issue i1 by claiming no jurisdiction despite s.645.
a11 responds to a5's claim of Art.14 violation by arguing reasonable classification with twin test elements

a11 explicitly claims ss.239/240 classification reasonable under Art.14 with intelligible differentia (company managers distinct, abuse of company affairs) and rational nexus to object (protect shareholders/creditors)
a11 directly addresses i7 by arguing classification satisfies reasonable classification test
The argument supports the interpretation of s. 138(4) (c5) by explaining the role of the Registrar's report in deciding inspector appointment without it being a formal complaint.
The argument addresses whether the Registrar's report under s. 138(4) constitutes a formal accusation affecting jurisdiction/vires under the Act scheme.
Argument that s.6 General Clauses Act applies subject to ss.645-657 supports the holding that s.645 authorizes the legal fiction deeming the inspector appointed under the new Act
Argument on s.6 General Clauses Act application subject to ss.645-657 addresses jurisdiction issue under new Act
